description.b: This cheat sheet is a tutorial about one feature of the Package Explorer: Label Decorators

item.title: Open the Label Decorator Preference Page
item.description: Label Decorators are used in the Package Explorer to display extra information about the resource files and/or folders. They can be enabled or disabled by going to 'Window -> Preferences -> General -> Appearance -> Label Decorations' or by clicking on the link below.

item.title: Enable/Disable Label Decorators
item.description: There are several Label Decorators available in the decorator preference page. The main ones are the following:

subitem.label: 1. File Metadata Decorator : it decorates all files with 'size, date of last modification, file permission (read, write, execute) and file owner(if on Unix)'. Try disabling it (click on the checkbox next to the decorator's name) then press 'Apply'. Make sure you have a list of resource files open in the package explorer in order to see it working. Re-enable it.

2. DAT File Scan Command Decorator : it decorates all DAT files with their corresponding Scan Command if there is one. It is displayed after the Metadata decoration. Try disabling it. Make sure you have a list of DAT files open in the package explorer in order to see it working. Re-enable it.

3. Nexus Scan Command and Title Decorator : it decorates all Nexus files with their corresponding Title and Scan Command if there are any. It is displayed below the Metadata decoration on a new line feed. Try disabling it. Make sure you have a list of Nexus files open in the package explorer in order to see it working. Re-enable it.

4. HDF5 Tree Element Decorator : it decorates all Tree Elements of an unfolded Nexus/HDF5 file with their corresponding data. It is displayed near by each tree element. Try disabling it. Make sure you have a Nexus/HDF5 file structure unfold in the package explorer in order to see it working. Re-enable it.
Note: depending on the amount of files in a folder, the decorators might take longer to get displayed. However they all run on separate jobs and should not block the SDA.
